title: Fred Smollan
text:
Frederick "Fred" Cecil Smollan (20 August 1908 – 8 February 1998, <a href="Johannesburg">Johannesburg</a>) was a <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">South Africa</a> international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player.
Career history.
Fred Smollan was born in <a href="Uitenhage">Uitenhage</a>, South Africa in 1908 to David Smollan and Mathilda Goldwater, the second of four brothers. Educated at <a href="Muir%20College">Muir College</a> and later <a href="Grey%20High%20School">Grey High School</a>, Smollan was only the second Jew to represent in rugby union, after <a href="Morris%20Zimerman">Morris Zimerman</a>. Smollan played club rugby for <a href="Wanderers%20RFC">Wanderers RFC</a>, regional rugby for <a href="Eastern%20Province%20Elephants">Eastern Province</a> and <a href="Golden%20Lions">Transvaal</a> and played three times for South Africa in 1933.
His three internationals were all against <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a> on the team's <a href="1933%20Australia%20rugby%20union%20tour%20of%20South%20Africa%20and%20Rhodesia">1933 tour</a> of South Africa. Although he would receive no further caps, he faced international opponents again, facing the <a href="1938%20British%20Lions%20tour%20to%20South%20Africa">1938 British Lions</a> as part of the Transvaal team. Transvaal defeated the Lions 16–9, with Smollan scoring one of the tries.
In 1931 he set up a business Smollan Holdings, initially as a sales agency. With the outbreak of World War II he served in North Africa. He married Molly Amelia Raphaely in Johannesburg in 1943 and after the war returned to run his business which he built into a public company. Smollan and Molly had two children, Doug (b. 1945) and Katherine (b. 1948). Smollan Holdings expanded to become the <a href="Smollan%20Group">Smollan Group</a>, a multinational company which now employs 34,000 people and outsources marketing services across the world. Smollan remained as its chairman until shortly before his death.
